text: Where do I file bugs?
37kb of extra bloat is being add _per_ form to the page. And I have the "Unstyled Form" option selected. Huge whoopsie? What is this?

Good morning.  I'm finishing up and testing the responsiveness on this CMS Developer Practicum, but I'm getting 2 entirely different results when I view with the HubSpot preview versus my browser's media preview.  Should I style for just the HS one, or do I need to do both?  Thanks.
cc <@UBFA10FMF> is the bug squashing guru :slightly_smiling_face:
cc <@U3PKJ8EQL>
:eyes:

Hmm. I don't know if this is an issue that should be surfaced to product folks, but for the sake of the practicum: I would rely on a standard browser preview and dragging the window to resize. The gif I have on the practicum requirements page shows resizing a screen that way. I don't want to be pushy about how folks do dev work, but I'm usually not a huge fan of those media preview features since the goal of responsiveness isn't specific device sizes but everything in between. If that makes sense.

The practicum is graded (like most QA in production situations) making sure that the 900px break point is where the columns switch and making sure they don't switch unexpectedly at other sizes. Feel free to DM if you want more info/clarification.
<@UKWPUPJ4W>
Thank you very much for the info.  The custom module/content is fine, I'm just trying to fine-tune the header and footer.
Sadly, it's also taking the longest lol
Lol. Ain't that always the way...
Every.  Time.  :wink:

Heya <@UL1S6TULB>! According to the team, we've always had that there- it's to ensure the form renders in a readable way even without styling. It's super basic styling just to keep minor layouts and ensure the form is still submittable without additional markup.

I’m not sure complex box-shadows could be justified here. What do you make on all of that? The css selectors do not relate to the form. If a user selects “unstyled form”, IMO it shouldn’t include this.
Honestly, looking at the code, this appears to be a glaring bug, not a feature. Not trying to offend anyone. Just improve performance. Thanks for listening.
is there any way to use sccs files in HubSpot or sass files
<@ULCLFG692> Not directly, but there is a really great new feature that was released this week that lets you develop HubSpot locally, so you can use whichever CSS extension you would like
I just added you to the channel
you can use sass locally and then ftp the compiled css to the HubSpot portal
the <#CLJJXGTC0|local-development> makes the uploading part really easy

Also, I’d like to note, you may not need scss unless scss nesting is impossible to live without.

Almost every other feature is possible using HubL(that’s right HubL is available in css and js files)

Hello -- I'm looking for some superstar HubSpot email template creators that are looking for some freelance work.... I get some requests for email creators from time to time and would love to make a connection or two that stays up to date on email viewer bugs, what works, what doesn't, etc. Send me a direct message if you are one of those amazing email people!!
:point_up: thats a fact, we've done things in a scss way with exception of nested items.
but as <@U7V9DQ31P> pointed out, the local dev beta is a good bet for this
Side perk of using HubL - you can use that HubL to do things in other files
autoprefixing + nesting
i can't live without those
<@UJL4N3WN8> - this seems like something up your alley
